title: SeQuest Manual — Arithmetic and Geometric Sequences & Series
topics: Real-World Applications of Sequences and Series

sections.title: Introduction
content: This manual provides a complete guide to Arithmetic and Geometric Sequences and Series.
It compiles every topic and concept from both Arithmetic and Geometric problem sets used in A-level and G-level exercises.
You will learn all the key formulas, relationships, and how to find unknown quantities like a[sub]1[/sub], d, r, n, Sₙ, and aₙ.
All definitions, formulas, and solving procedures are provided for study and quick reference.

sections.title: Common Symbols and Definitions
content: a [sub]1[/sub] — first term of the sequence
aₙ — nth term (any term in the sequence)
d — common difference (arithmetic sequence)
r — common ratio (geometric sequence)
n — number of terms or term position
Sₙ — sum of the first n terms (finite series)
S∞ — sum to infinity (only for convergent geometric series, |r| < 1)
l — last term (used in arithmetic series)
Σ — summation notation, representing the total sum of a series

sections.title: Arithmetic Sequence
content: An Arithmetic Sequence (A.S.) is a sequence of numbers where each term after the first is obtained by adding a constant difference (d).
General Form: a [sub] 1 [/sub], a [sub] 1 [/sub] + d, a [sub] 1 [/sub] + 2d, a [sub] 1 [/sub] + 3d, ...
nth Term Formula: aₙ = a [sub] 1 [/sub] + (n − 1)d
Common Difference: d = a₂ − a [sub] 1 [/sub] or d = (aₙ − a [sub] 1 [/sub]) / (n − 1)
To find n when aₙ is known: n = ((aₙ − a [sub] 1 [/sub]) / d) + 1
If a term’s position is not an integer, that term does not exist in the sequence.

sections.title: Arithmetic Series (Sum of Arithmetic Sequence)
content: An Arithmetic Series is the sum of the first n terms of an arithmetic sequence.
Formula using first and last term: Sₙ = (n/2)(a [sub] 1 [/sub] + l)
Formula using common difference: Sₙ = (n/2)[2a [sub] 1 [/sub] + (n − 1)d]
Relationship between last term and first term: l = a [sub] 1 [/sub] + (n − 1)d
If d = 0, all terms are equal and Sₙ = n × a [sub] 1 [/sub].
To find n given Sₙ, rearrange the sum formula into a quadratic: d n² + (2a [sub] 1 [/sub] − d)n − 2Sₙ = 0, and solve for n.

sections.title: Geometric Sequence
content: A Geometric Sequence (G.S.) is a sequence of numbers where each term is obtained by multiplying the previous term by a fixed ratio (r).
General Form: a [sub] 1 [/sub], a₁r, a₁r², a₁r³, ...
nth Term Formula: aₙ = a₁ × r^(n − 1)
Common Ratio: r = a₂ / a [sub] 1 [/sub] or r = (aₙ / a [sub] 1 [/sub])^(1 / (n − 1))
To find a₁ given aₙ and r: a [sub] 1 [/sub] = aₙ / r^(n − 1)
To find n when aₙ, a₁, and r are known: n = [log(aₙ / a [sub] 1 [/sub]) / log(r)] + 1
If r > 1, the sequence grows (exponential growth). If 0 < r < 1, the sequence decreases (exponential decay).

sections.title: Geometric Series (Sum of Geometric Sequence)
content: A Geometric Series is the sum of the first n terms of a geometric sequence.
Formula (r ≠ 1): Sₙ = a [sub] 1 [/sub] × (rⁿ − 1) / (r − 1)
If r < 1, you can also use: Sₙ = a [sub] 1 [/sub] × (1 − rⁿ) / (1 − r)
Relationship with next term: Sₙ = (a [sub] 1 [/sub] − a [sub] 1 [/sub] rⁿ) / (1 − r) = (a [sub] 1 [/sub] − aₙ₊₁) / (1 − r)
To find a₁ given Sₙ, r, and n: a₁ = Sₙ × (r − 1) / (rⁿ − 1)
To find r when a₁, aₙ, and n are known: r = (aₙ / a [sub] 1 [/sub] )^(1 / (n − 1))

sections.title: Infinite Geometric Series
content: When the ratio r satisfies |r| < 1, the geometric series has a finite sum even as n → ∞.
Formula: S∞ = a [sub] 1 [/sub] / (1 − r)
If |r| ≥ 1, the series diverges and has no finite sum.
For alternating ratios (negative r), the terms alternate in sign, but convergence still depends on |r| < 1.
Infinite series are common in real-life applications like physics, finance, and computer science (e.g., repeated depreciation, signal decay, or iterative algorithms).

sections.title: Arithmetic vs Geometric Comparison
content: Arithmetic sequences involve addition or subtraction of a fixed amount (d).
Geometric sequences involve multiplication or division by a fixed amount (r).
Arithmetic: linear growth or decay — constant difference.
Geometric: exponential growth or decay — constant ratio.
Example comparison:
A.S.: 2, 4, 6, 8, 10 → difference d = 2
Graphically, arithmetic sequences form straight lines, while geometric sequences form exponential curves.

sections.title: Real-World Applications of Sequences and Series
content: 1. Compound Interest — Geometric sequence with r = 1 + (interest rate).
2. Population Growth — Each generation multiplies by a growth rate (geometric).
3. Radioactive Decay — Successive quantities form a geometric decay series (0 < r < 1).
4. Depreciation of Assets — Value decreases geometrically over time.
5. Loan Payments and Investments — Use arithmetic or geometric series to model total payments or accumulated value.
6. Physics and Engineering — Patterns of vibrations, waves, or signal loss can follow geometric series.
7. Repeated Patterns or Tilings — Arithmetic and geometric progressions describe spacing, scaling, or layering.

sections.title: Step-by-Step Solving Guide
content: 1. Identify the sequence type (arithmetic or geometric).
2. Write down known variables (a₁, aₙ, d/r, n, Sₙ).
3. Choose the appropriate formula based on what you are solving for.
4. Rearrange formula algebraically to isolate the unknown.
5. Substitute values carefully.
6. Simplify and interpret your result — ensure n is a positive integer when required.
7. For series, verify conditions (|r| < 1 for convergence).

sections.title: Formula Summary
content: Arithmetic Sequence: aₙ = a [sub] 1 [/sub] + (n − 1)d
Arithmetic Series: Sₙ = (n/2)(2a [sub] 1 [/sub] + (n − 1)d)
Arithmetic Last Term: l = a [sub] 1 [/sub] + (n − 1)d
Geometric Sequence: aₙ = a [sub] 1 [/sub] × r^(n − 1)
Geometric Series: Sₙ = a [sub] 1 [/sub] × (rⁿ − 1) / (r − 1)
Infinite Geometric Series: S∞ = a [sub] 1 [/sub] / (1 − r)
Find d: d = (aₙ − a [sub] 1 [/sub] ) / (n − 1)
Find r: r = (aₙ / a [sub] 1 [/sub] )^(1 / (n − 1))
Find n (Arithmetic): n = ((aₙ − a [sub] 1 [/sub] ) / d) + 1
Find n (Geometric): n = [log(aₙ / a [sub] 1 [/sub]) / log(r)] + 1
Find a₁ (Geometric): a [sub] 1 [/sub] = aₙ / r^(n − 1)
Find a₁ (Arithmetic): a [sub] 1 [/sub] = aₙ − (n − 1)d

sections.title: Tips and Checks
content: Always check the type of sequence before applying a formula.
For arithmetic, check if the difference is constant.
For geometric, check if the ratio is constant.
When solving for n, ensure your answer is a positive integer.
Use logarithms only for geometric equations involving powers.
For infinite series, ensure |r| < 1 before using S∞ formula.
In word problems, translate situations into a₁, r/d, and n carefully (e.g., years, months, intervals).
Use the rearranged form a [sub] 1 [/sub] = Sₙ × (r − 1)/(rⁿ − 1) when finding first term from total sum.

content: This manual integrates all covered concepts from A-level and G-level progression data:
